Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that a federal judge has granted permission to subpoena Trump, when in fact the judge's ruling only allows the plaintiffs to serve document preservation subpoenas on Trump-owned companies.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or details to back up the statement that a federal judge has granted permission to subpoena Trump.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the ruling allowing document preservation subpoenas on Trump-owned companies automatically means that Trump himself will be subpoenaed.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not accurately representing the judge's ruling and misinterpreting it as permission to subpoena Trump.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the judge's ruling does not specifically mention subpoenaing Trump.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the ruling only allows for the preservation of documents and does not directly involve subpoenaing Trump.
